citation.article-title: Roseomonas, a new genus associated with bacteremia and other human infections.

p.s: Description of Roseomonas cervicalis sp. nov.
Roseomonas cervicalis (cer.vi.ca'lis. M.L. adj. cervicalis, from the cervix)
R. cervicalis exhibits all of the characteristics of the genus.
It does not hydrolyze esculin or reduce nitrates.
It is motile and oxidizes fructose but does not oxidize D-galactose, glycerol, D-glucose, D-mannitol, or D-mannose.
Oxidation of L-arabinose, D-xylose, and salicin and citrate utilization are variable.
The biochemical characteristics of use in differentiating R. cervicalis from other Roseomonas species are given in Table 2.
The GC contents of three strains are 67.5 to 70.4 mol%. R. cervicalis is pathogenic for humans, causing urogenital, eye, and other infections.
It has a GC content of 70.4 mol%.
It was isolated in 1980 from the cervix of a woman in New Jersey.
